{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3441826,"name":"James Gladden","username":"Jim1949","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/8baadc/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-10-30T18:21:28.559Z","cooked":"

I’m curious as to peoples thinking about the bumper rule changes for 2025.

firstinspires.org

2025-Bumper-Rule-Changes.pdf

284.22 KB

The memo indicates that two new materials will be allowed/recommended for cushioning in bumpers:

  1. Solid Polyethylene (PE) closed cell foam with density between 1.5 and 3
    lb/cu ft.

  2. Solid Ethylene-Vinyl Acetate (EVA) closed cell foam with density between
    2 and 6 lb/cu ft.

Is there any good reason to believe that one of those two materials is superior to the other from a robot protection standpoint? Based on a little looking around, it appears that the PE closed cell foam is less expensive and maybe easier to obtain (Home Depot sells 1" thick sheets of 2 lb/cu ft material)

There’s a lot of discussion about it here:

[FRC Blog]: Field and Robot Damage Update General Forum
This blog is the final blog on the task forces we created over the off-season. Over the past few seasons, teams and participants have seen an increase in robot and field damage. We have been evaluating ways to reduce damage to ensure that participants are safe during match play, robots are able to participate throughout the season with a reasonable amount of maintenance, field elements are robust enough to hold up through the full competition season, and that matches remain fun and exciting t…

Please continue the discussion there.

Closing this thread.
